text:
Tough time to be a Chipotle lover. The stock’s fallen 35% in recent months, largely due to food safety concerns. Today, the company announced they're closing all stores nationwide for a few hours on February 8th to discuss these issues with employees.
But investors looking forward want more – they want profits. It seems clear that investors believe the "better" days (see: growth) are in the rear-view for this once-beloved stock. The main issues at hand are:
1. Growth has slowed: Chipotle’s same-store sales growth was around 10% annually from 2010-2015, peaking at 16.6% in Q3 of 2014. But since then it's dwindled; Q3 of 2015 only saw a 2% growth.
2. Expanding costs and flat profit margins: While top-line revenue is up, bottom line earnings haven’t followed as quickly, causing worry among shareholders. Increased spending on marketing and staffing may improve brand trust & customer satisfaction eventually… but that's harder to prove than the cost itself.
To be successful again, Chipotle should focus on improving their food quality, safety, and efficiency across their network to drive sales...and eventually profit margin rebounds. Meanwhile, share buybacks or cost-cutting could boost EPS expectations, appeasing jittery investors.
